contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (d) if subsection 8(2) applies and the medicine: (i) includes one or more active ingredients, the name of which includes descriptors (for example chemical salts or hydration states) that are not therapeutically relevant; and (ii) the name and quantity or proportion of each of those active ingredients is displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), then the name of the therapeutically active moiety(ies) of the active ingredient may be displayed on the main label on the primary pack, instead of the name of the active ingredient, if: (iii) this is in a text size of not less than 3.0 millimetres; and (iv) no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients in the medicine.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (f) The presentation of the critical health information, and any information mentioned in paragraphs 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) that is included, must be presented in black or other dark coloured texts, using only one colour, on a white or other contrasting background.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine's main label on the primary pack displays the name and quantity of an active ingredient that has a non-therapeutically relevant descriptor in accordance with subsection 8(2), can the name of the therapeutically active moiety be displayed instead of the active ingredient name if the text size is 2.5 millimeters and no quantity information is shown?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 9(7)(d), if a medicine's active ingredient name includes non-therapeutically relevant descriptors and the name and quantity are displayed per 8(2), the therapeutically active moiety name can be displayed instead only if the text size is at least 3.0 millimeters and no quantity information is shown for any active ingredients. Since the given text size is 2.5 millimeters, the conditions are not met to allow displaying the moiety name instead of the full active ingredient name.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label includes critical health information and the information required by 8(2)(c), (d) and (e), what color text and background must be used to present this information?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The text must be black or dark colored, using only one color, on a white or contrasting background.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 8(2)(f) states that the critical health information and any information from 8(2)(c), (d) or (e) that is included must be presented in black or other dark colored text, using only one color, on a white or other contrasting background.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered goods and its active ingredient name has non-therapeutically relevant descriptors, if the active ingredient name and quantity are shown on the main label per 8(2) with 4mm text and no quantity is shown, can the therapeutically active moiety name be displayed instead of the full active ingredient name?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(7)(d) allows the therapeutically active moiety name to be displayed on the main label instead of the full active ingredient name if: the medicine is registered goods, the active ingredient name has non-relevant descriptors, the name and quantity are shown per 8(2), the moiety name text size is at least 3.0mm, and no quantity is shown for any active ingredients. The scenario meets all these conditions, with the 4mm text exceeding the 3mm minimum, so displaying the moiety name is permitted.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label must display certain information required by 8(2)(c)-(e), can the text be in multiple colors if a white background is used?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 8(2)(f) requires that any information from 8(2)(c), (d) or (e) must be presented in black or dark colored text using only one color on a white or contrasting background. Using multiple text colors is not permitted even if the background is white.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (c) (i) the total number of active ingredients in the different formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit are to be counted; and (ii) if the same active ingredient is contained in two or more formulations in the composite pack or medicine kit, each of those active ingredients is to be counted separately, for the purposes of determining if paragraph 9(6)(b) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit, or which paragraph in subsection 9(7) applies to the composite pack or medicine kit; and

9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (d) if subsection 8(2) applies and the medicine: (i) includes one or more active ingredients, the name of which includes descriptors (for example chemical salts or hydration states) that are not therapeutically relevant; and (ii) the name and quantity or proportion of each of those active ingredients is displayed in accordance with subsection 8(2), then the name of the therapeutically active moiety(ies) of the active ingredient may be displayed on the main label on the primary pack, instead of the name of the active ingredient, if: (iii) this is in a text size of not less than 3.0 millimetres; and (iv) no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients in the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a composite pack contains multiple medicines with the same active ingredient in different formulations, how would the number of active ingredients be counted for determining which labeling requirements apply under sections 9(6)(b) or 9(7)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Each instance of the same active ingredient would be counted separately.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(8)(c)(ii) states that if the same active ingredient is contained in two or more formulations in a composite pack, each of those active ingredients is to be counted separately for the purposes of determining if paragraph 9(6)(b) applies or which paragraph in 9(7) applies to the labeling of the composite pack.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered medicine that includes active ingredients with therapeutically irrelevant name descriptors, what conditions must be met to display the therapeutically active moiety names instead of the full active ingredient names on the main label, assuming the requirements of section 8(2) are followed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The moiety names must be in a text size of at least 3.0mm and no quantity or proportion information can be displayed for any of the active ingredients.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(d) allows the therapeutically active moiety names to be displayed instead of the full active ingredient names on the main label of a registered medicine, provided that: the requirements of 8(2) for displaying ingredient names and quantities are met, the moiety names are in a text size of at least 3.0mm, and no quantity or proportion information is displayed for any of the active ingredients.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a composite pack containing multiple medicines. One medicine has two active ingredients, Chemical A and Chemical B. Another medicine in the pack also contains Chemical A in a different formulation. Assuming no other active ingredients are present, how many total active ingredients would be counted for the composite pack when determining applicable labeling requirements?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The composite pack would be considered to have three active ingredients in total.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Based on sections 9(8)(c)(i) and (ii), the total number of active ingredients in the different formulations are counted, and if the same active ingredient is in multiple formulations, each instance is counted separately. So Chemical A would be counted twice (once for each formulation) and Chemical B once, totaling three active ingredients for labeling purposes.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered medicine named 'Example' that follows the naming requirements in section 8(2), can the therapeutically active moiety name be displayed on the main label instead of the full active ingredient name if the active ingredient name includes a chemical salt that is not therapeutically relevant?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, provided the moiety name has a text size of at least 3.0mm and no quantity or proportion is displayed for any active ingredient.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(d) permits the therapeutically active moiety name to be displayed on the main label of the registered medicine 'Example' instead of the full active ingredient name when: 'Example' follows 8(2) naming requirements, the active ingredient name includes a therapeutically irrelevant chemical salt, the moiety name text size is minimum 3.0mm, and active ingredient quantities/proportions are not displayed.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (f) The presentation of the critical health information, and any information mentioned in paragraphs 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) that is included, must be presented in black or other dark coloured texts, using only one colour, on a white or other contrasting background.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the critical health information, including information mentioned in 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e), is being presented on a medicine label, what colour text and background must be used?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The critical health information and any included information from 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) must be presented in black or other dark coloured text, using only one colour, on a white or other contrasting background.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: This is directly stated in regulation 8(2)(f). It specifies the required text and background colours for presenting the critical health information and other information from 8(2)(c), 8(2)(d) or 8(2)(e) on the label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If information other than the critical health information or that mentioned in 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is included on a medicine label, under what heading should it be placed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If other information is included beyond the critical health information and that from 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d), it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Regulation 8(2)(e) states the requirement for where to place other information on the label beyond the critical health information and that from 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(d). It must go under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading below those from 8(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming other information is included under the 'Other information' heading as per 8(2)(e), what are the only additional details that can be included there?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If other information is included under the 'Other information' heading, the only additional details allowed are: requirements relating to storage conditions, information about package features to prevent tampering, names of all excipients, and sponsor or distributor contact details.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: The list of allowable additional details under the 'Other information' heading is explicitly provided in regulation 8(2)(e). No other additional information beyond those listed items is permitted.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the given regulations, how should the critical health information be visually presented on the label in relation to any other information allowed under 8(2)(e)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The critical health information must be presented in black or dark coloured text on a white or contrasting background, separate from and above any other information allowed under the 'Other information' heading as per 8(2)(e).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Regulation 8(2)(f) mandates the visual presentation of the critical health information in dark text on a contrasting background. Regulation 8(2)(e) states that any other information must be placed under a separate 'Other information' heading below the critical information. Taken together, the regulations require the critical health information to be visually distinct and positioned above the other information on the label.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (c) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (1) Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order, the information on the main label of the medicine must include: (c) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (b) If, in relation to a medicine referred to in (a) there are: (i) four or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods; or (ii) two or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods, then, in relation to compliance of the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the following information is displayed: (iii) the name of the medicine; and (iv) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and (v) the expiry date of the medicine preceded by the expiry date prefix; and (vi) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

9 Information to be included on the main label (6) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods: (a) if the medicine is a sunscreen preparation - the name of every active ingredient, together with the quantity or proportion of every active ingredient, and the name of the dosage form, may appear on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a listed medicine has 3 active ingredients and is intended to be in a blister pack, what information must be displayed on the label of the blister pack to comply with sections 8 and 9 of the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine, batch number preceded by the batch number prefix, expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix, and the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(ii) states that for listed goods with 2 or more active ingredients in a strip, blister or dial dispenser pack, to comply with sections 8 and 9, the label must display the name of the medicine (iii), batch number with prefix (iv), expiry date with prefix (v), and name of sponsor/distributor or identifying trademark (vi).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a listed medicine is a sunscreen preparation intended to be in a container with a main label and rear label, can the active ingredients and their quantities be listed on the rear label and still comply with section 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, for a listed sunscreen preparation, the name, quantity and proportion of every active ingredient, along with the dosage form name, may appear on a rear label and still comply with section 9.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(6)(a) allows that for a listed medicine that is a sunscreen preparation, the name of every active ingredient, together with the quantity or proportion of every active ingredient, and the name of the dosage form, may appear on a rear panel or rear label and still comply with the section 9 labeling requirements for the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine has 5 active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods in a blister pack, what information must the label on the blister pack display to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine, batch number preceded by the batch number prefix, expiry date preceded by the expiry date prefix, and the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(i) states that for registered goods with 4 or more active ingredients in a strip, blister or dial dispenser pack, to comply with sections 8 and 9, the label must display the name of the medicine (iii), batch number with prefix (iv), expiry date with prefix (v), and name of sponsor/distributor or identifying trademark (vi).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a listed medicine has 1 active ingredient and is intended to be in a dial dispenser pack, is the information required in section 10(9)(b)(iii)-(vi) sufficient for the label to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, section 10(9)(b) only provides reduced labeling requirements for listed goods in a dial dispenser pack if the medicine has 2 or more active ingredients. With only 1 active ingredient, the label would need to fully comply with all of sections 8 and 9.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(ii) specifies that the reduced labeling requirements in (iii)-(vi) for strip, blister or dial dispenser packs only apply to listed goods with 2 or more active ingredients. Therefore, a listed medicine with only 1 active ingredient would not qualify for this, and would need to have a label fully compliant with sections 8 and 9.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (5) Sunscreen preparations If: (b) is enclosed in a container with a capacity of not more than 25 millilitres, then, in relation to compliance with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if (i) the sun protection factor is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres; and (ii) all other information is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.0 millimetres.

9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a sunscreen preparation is in a 20 ml container, what is the minimum font size required for the sun protection factor and all other information on the label to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 1.5 mm for sun protection factor, 1.0 mm for all other information
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(b) states that for sunscreen preparations in containers of 25 ml or less, the sun protection factor must be displayed in a text size of at least 1.5 mm and all other information in at least 1.0 mm to comply with sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: If a medicine's main label lists the active ingredients separated by text identifying different formulations in a composite pack, does this violate the labeling requirements? Assume no other exceptions apply.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, it does not violate the requirements.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(3)(b) requires the medicine name and active ingredients to not be separated by any text or graphics. However, 9(3)(b)(ii) provides an exception for text relating to identifying different formulations of medicines in a composite pack. So separating the ingredients by such text is permitted and does not violate the requirements.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a 15 ml sunscreen container lists the SPF in 1.5 mm text and other info in 0.8 mm text, and no other exceptions apply, does the label meet the minimum text size requirements of sections 8-10?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the label does not meet the minimum text size requirements.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(5)(b) allows sunscreens 25 ml or less to have the SPF in minimum 1.5 mm text (which is met) and all other info in minimum 1.0 mm text. However, the other info is in 0.8 mm text which is less than the 1.0 mm minimum required by 10(5)(b)(ii) to comply with sections 8-9. No other exceptions are stated to apply.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a 30 ml sunscreen, can the active ingredients on the main label be separated by text indicating the product is part of a composite pack of different formulations? Assume sections 8-9 are met.
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the active ingredients can be separated by that text.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(3)(b) generally prohibits medicine names and active ingredients from being separated by text. However, 9(3)(b)(ii) allows separating them with text identifying different formulations in a composite pack. Section 10(5)(b) text size allowances only apply to sunscreens 25 ml or less. At 30 ml, this sunscreen does not get that allowance, but sections 8-9 are assumed to be met, so the composite pack text exception in 9(3)(b)(ii) applies without violating the regulations.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (b) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and the quantities or proportions of the active ingredients may be included on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label, when displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the non-prescription medicine has four active ingredients, no critical health information, and storage condition B information needs to be included, where on the label should the names and quantities of the active ingredients be placed, and where should the storage condition B information be placed?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities of the active ingredients should be placed on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label in a text size of at least 2.5 millimetres. The storage condition B information should be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 9(7)(b), if the medicine has four or more active ingredients and section 8(2) does not apply, the names and quantities of the active ingredients may be placed on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label, with a text size of at least 2.5 millimetres. Section 8(2)(e) states that if information other than critical health information or information mentioned in 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is included, such as storage conditions, it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading immediately below the headings in 8(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine has five active ingredients and no critical health information, can the names and quantities of the active ingredients be placed on the rear label if displayed in a text size of 2.0 millimetres?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the names and quantities of the active ingredients cannot be placed on the rear label if displayed in a text size of 2.0 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(b) allows the names and quantities of active ingredients to be placed on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label only if the text size is at least 2.5 millimetres. Since the given text size is 2.0 millimetres, which is less than the required 2.5 millimetres, placing the information on the rear label would not comply with the regulation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine has three active ingredients, no critical health information, and sponsor contact details need to be included, where should the sponsor contact details be placed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The sponsor contact details should be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(e) states that if information other than critical health information or information mentioned in 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is included, such as sponsor contact details, it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine has six active ingredients and no critical health information, can the names and quantities of the active ingredients be placed on the rear label if displayed in a text size of 3.0 millimetres, and can storage condition B information be placed under the same heading as the names of excipients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the names and quantities of the active ingredients can be placed on the rear label if displayed in a text size of 3.0 millimetres, as this complies with section 9(7)(b). However, storage condition B information cannot be placed under the same heading as the names of excipients, as section 8(2)(e) requires storage condition information to be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading, separate from the names of excipients.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(7)(b) allows the names and quantities of active ingredients to be placed on a side panel, side label, rear panel, or rear label if the text size is at least 2.5 millimetres. Since the given text size is 3.0 millimetres, placing the information on the rear label complies with the regulation. However, section 8(2)(e) requires storage condition information to be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading, separate from other information such as the names of excipients. Therefore, placing storage condition B information under the same heading as the names of excipients would not comply with the regulation.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "critical health information" means information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) of this Order, that is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (c) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label only includes the quantity of active ingredients, but is missing all other critical health information, would this label meet the requirements specified in the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 6, 'critical health information' includes the information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n), which is critical for safe use of self-selected medicines. Section 8(1)(c) states that the quantity of active ingredients must be included on the label. However, if the label is missing the other pieces of critical health information required by 8(1)(b), (j), (k), (l) and (n), it would not meet the requirements specified in the given regulation sections for safe use of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes all critical health information except the quantity of active ingredients, would this label meet the requirements for safe use as specified in the given regulation sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines 'critical health information' as the information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n), which is critical for safe use of self-selected medicines. Section 8(1)(c) specifically states that the quantity of active ingredients must be included on the label. If this information is missing, even if all other pieces of critical health information are present, the label would not meet the requirements for safe use as specified in the given regulation sections.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine label includes the quantity of active ingredients as well as all other critical health information specified in section 8(1), would this label meet the interpretation of 'critical health information' for safe use defined in section 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 defines 'critical health information' as the information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) that is critical for safe use of self-selected medicines. Section 8(1)(c) states that the quantity of active ingredients must be included on the label. Therefore, if a label includes the quantity of active ingredients per 8(1)(c), as well as all the other pieces of critical health information required by 8(1)(b), (j), (k), (l) and (n), it would meet the interpretation of 'critical health information' for safe use as defined in section 6.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the label of a non-prescription medicine includes all required information specified in section 8(1) except paragraphs (b), (j), (k), (l) and (n), would this label be considered to have 'critical health information' for safe use as per the interpretation in section 6?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 6 interprets 'critical health information' as the information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) that is critical for safe use of self-selected medicines. While section 8(1)(c) regarding the quantity of active ingredients may be included, if the label is missing the information required by paragraphs 8(1)(b), (j), (k), (l) and (n), it would not be considered to have the 'critical health information' necessary for safe use as per the interpretation provided in section 6.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (g) for preparations applied to the skin and mucous membranes, other than those covered by paragraph (f) - as a percentage expressed in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate, or as the weight or volume in a stated weight or volume of the medicine, as appropriate;

11 How information is to be expressed (2) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients Subject to paragraph 11(2)(i) and subsection 11(3) below, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient to be included on a label must be expressed: (f) for pressurised metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products such as nasal sprays, the quantity of the active ingredient is: (i) the quantity delivered per actuation; or where the Secretary, when registering the medicine, has accepted that the dose of products containing those active ingredients was clinically established as the metered dose, then: (ii) the quantity metered per actuation;

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a pressurised metered dose inhaler contains an active ingredient and the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when the medicine was registered, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(ii), for pressurised metered dose inhalers where the Secretary accepted that the dose was clinically established as the metered dose when registering the medicine, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity metered per actuation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a topical cream contains an active ingredient, how should the quantity or proportion of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity or proportion of the active ingredient should be expressed as a percentage in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate, or as the weight or volume in a stated weight or volume of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(g), for preparations applied to the skin and mucous membranes other than pressurised metered dose inhalers, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient must be expressed as a percentage in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate, or as the weight or volume in a stated weight or volume of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a nasal spray contains an active ingredient and is a metered dose product, how should the quantity of the active ingredient be expressed on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(f)(i), for pressurised metered dose inhalers, dry powder inhalers and other metered dose products such as nasal sprays, the quantity of the active ingredient should be expressed as the quantity delivered per actuation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an ointment contains an active ingredient and is not a pressurised metered dose inhaler, how should the quantity or proportion of the active ingredient be expressed on the label in terms of w/w?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity or proportion of the active ingredient should be expressed as a percentage in terms of w/w.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(2)(g), for preparations applied to the skin and mucous membranes other than pressurised metered dose inhalers, the quantity or proportion of an active ingredient must be expressed as a percentage in terms of w/w, w/v, v/v or v/w, as appropriate. Since the question specifies w/w, the answer is that it should be expressed as a percentage in terms of w/w.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (5) If the container is enclosed in a delivery device such that it cannot be removed, the information required on its label under subsection 8(1) must be applied on the delivery device and not the container.

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (k) relevant warning statements, where these are required in relation to a particular medicine or in specified circumstances applying to a particular medicine, such as the following: (i) where the medicine is for external use the required statement is ‘Caution: Not to be Swallowed’ or ‘For External Use Only’ or words to this effect; (ii) where: (A) the medicine is for oral use; and (B) the medicine contains active ingredient(s) included in category 'B' (including 'B1', 'B2', 'B3') or category 'C' in the document titled ‘Prescribing medicines in pregnancy database’ published on the TGA website as on the date of commencement of this Order; and (C) the medicine is not subject to other specific warning statement(s) relating to use during pregnancy, the required statement is: ‘If pregnant or likely to become pregnant, consult a pharmacist or a doctor before use’ or words to this effect; and (iii) where: (A) the medicine is a registered goods for oral use; and (B) the medicine contains active ingredient(s) included in category ‘D’ (except nicotine for smoking cessation) in the document titled ‘Prescribing medicines in pregnancy database’ published on the TGA website as at the date of commencement of this Order; and (C) the medicine is not subject to other specific warning statements(s) relating to use during pregnancy, the required statement is ‘Do not use this medicine if pregnant or likely to become pregnant’ or words to this effect; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient in category B of the 'Prescribing medicines in pregnancy database', is for oral use, and has no other specific pregnancy warning, what warning statement is required on the label if the medicine is in a container that cannot be removed from its delivery device?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The required warning statement is: 'If pregnant or likely to become pregnant, consult a pharmacist or a doctor before use' or words to this effect.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(k)(ii) states that for an oral medicine containing a category B ingredient with no other specific pregnancy warnings, the required label statement is 'If pregnant or likely to become pregnant, consult a pharmacist or a doctor before use' or similar wording. Section 8(5) specifies that if the container cannot be removed from the delivery device, the required label information must be on the delivery device. Together, these sections indicate the pregnancy warning must appear on the delivery device in this scenario.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered oral medicine containing a category D ingredient (except nicotine for smoking cessation) and no other specific pregnancy warnings, assuming the container can be removed from the delivery device, what pregnancy warning is required and where must it appear?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The required warning statement 'Do not use this medicine if pregnant or likely to become pregnant' or similar wording must appear on the label of the container.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(k)(iii) mandates the warning 'Do not use this medicine if pregnant or likely to become pregnant' or similar for a registered oral medicine with a category D ingredient (excluding nicotine for smoking cessation) and no other specific pregnancy warnings. Since section 8(5) about delivery devices preventing container removal does not apply, the default rule in 8(1) locating the required information on the container label governs in this case.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an external use medicine is in a container that cannot be removed from the delivery device, what warning statement is required and where must the information appear?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The required warning statement 'Caution: Not to be Swallowed' or 'For External Use Only' or similar wording must appear on the delivery device, not the container.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(k)(i) requires the warning 'Caution: Not to be Swallowed', 'For External Use Only', or similar for external use medicines. Section 8(5) states that when the container cannot be removed from the delivery device, the required label information in 8(1) must go on the delivery device rather than the container. Combining these provisions, the external use warning must be on the delivery device in this scenario.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose an oral medicine contains both a category B and a category D ingredient from the 'Prescribing medicines in pregnancy database', with no other specific pregnancy warnings. Assuming the container is removable from the delivery device, what pregnancy warning statement is required on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The required warning statement is 'Do not use this medicine if pregnant or likely to become pregnant' or words to this effect.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: While section 8(1)(k)(ii) requires a certain pregnancy warning for category B ingredients, section 8(1)(k)(iii) mandates a stronger warning for category D ingredients in oral medicines. When a medicine contains both, the category D warning takes precedence as the stricter requirement. Since 8(5) does not apply when the container is removable, this warning goes on the container label per the default rule in 8(1).

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (8) Individually wrapped medicines (c) Where: (i) a medicine consists of dry herbs contained in individual bags and the bag is retained around the herbs during preparation; (ii) the bags are contained in a primary pack, the label of which complies with the requirements of this Order, then the individual bag need not be labelled with the information referred to in sections 8 and 9.
9 Information to be included on the main label (10) Subsection 9(9) does not apply: (a) where the medicine is supplied in a small container; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an individually wrapped herbal medicine consists of dry herbs in a bag that is retained during preparation, and the bags are in a primary pack with a compliant label, does each individual bag need to be labelled with the information in sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the individual bag does not need to be labelled with the information in sections 8 and 9.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(c) states that if a medicine consists of dry herbs in individual bags retained during preparation, and the bags are in a primary pack with a compliant label, then the individual bags do not need to be labelled with the information referred to in sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in a small container, does the exemption in subsection 9(10)(a) apply to the labelling requirements in subsection 9(9)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the exemption in subsection 9(10)(a) applies to the labelling requirements in subsection 9(9) for medicines supplied in small containers.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(10)(a) explicitly states that subsection 9(9) does not apply where the medicine is supplied in a small container.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an individually wrapped herbal medicine consists of dry herbs in bags retained during preparation, the bags are in a primary pack with a compliant label, and the primary pack is a small container, do the individual bags need to include the information from section 9(9)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the individual bags do not need to include the information from section 9(9).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(c) exempts the individual bags from the labelling requirements in sections 8 and 9 if they are in a compliant primary pack. Additionally, section 9(10)(a) exempts medicines in small containers from the requirements of section 9(9). Therefore, the individual bags are exempt from section 9(9) based on both the primary pack exemption and the small container exemption.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of dry herbs in individual bags that are not retained during preparation, and the bags are supplied in a small container serving as the primary pack, do the individual bags need to be labelled with the information in sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the individual bags need to be labelled with the information in sections 8 and 9.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(c) only exempts individual bags from the labelling requirements in sections 8 and 9 if the bags are retained during preparation and are in a primary pack with a compliant label. In this case, the bags are not retained during preparation, so the exemption does not apply. Section 9(10)(a) exempts small containers from the requirements of section 9(9), but not from the rest of sections 8 and 9. Therefore, the individual bags must be labelled with the applicable information from sections 8 and 9.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (5) If the medicine contains: (c) if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and (i) subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names, and quantities or proportions, of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or (ii) subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

9 Information to be included on the main label (1) Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order, the information on the main label of the medicine must include: (c) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is registered goods and contains one active ingredient, what is the minimum text size requirement for displaying the name and quantity or proportion of the active ingredient on the main label if subsection 8(2) does not apply?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 2.5 millimetres
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(i) states that if the medicine is registered goods, contains active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres. Section 9(1)(c) also generally requires the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients to be included on the main label, subject to the specific requirements in section 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, is it required to include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients on the main label as per section 9(1)(c)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(ii) provides that if the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with section 9(1)(c), which requires the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients to be included on the main label, is not required. This is an exception to the general requirement in 9(1)(c).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a non-prescription medicine is not registered goods, what information about the active ingredients is required on the main label as per the provided sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity or proportion of all active ingredients must be included on the main label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(1)(c) states that subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in section 9, the information on the main label of the medicine must include the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients. For medicines that are not registered goods, the exception in 9(5)(c) for registered goods does not apply, so the general requirement in 9(1)(c) stands.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Do the provided sections specify any qualifications or exceptions to the general requirement in section 9(1) to include certain information like active ingredient quantities on the main label of non-prescription medicines?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(1) states that the requirements to include information like the quantity or proportion of active ingredients in 9(1)(c) are 'Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order'. Section 9(5)(c)(ii) then provides a qualification that compliance with 9(1)(c) is not required if the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies. So there are specified qualifications and exceptions to the requirements in 9(1).

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (a) Subject to paragraph (b), if: (i) a medicine consists of individual dosage units such as tablets, capsules, pills, pastilles, cachets, lozenges, pessaries, suppositories or single doses of powder; and (ii) two or more dosage units are individually enclosed in a strip, blister or dial dispenser pack such that the dosage units can only be extracted individually; and (iii) the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack is enclosed in a primary pack, the label of which complies with sections 8 and 9, then, in relation to compliance of the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the following information is displayed: (iv) the name of the medicine; and (v) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and (vi) the quantity or proportion of all active ingredients in the medicine; and (vii) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and (viii) the expiry date of the medicine preceded by the expiry date prefix; and (ix) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

9 Information to be included on the main label (9) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and the name of an active ingredient included in the medicine comprises an ingredient name specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, then the names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of individually enclosed suppositories in a blister pack, which is enclosed in a labeled primary pack, what information must be displayed on the label of the blister pack if the active ingredient name is listed in Schedule 2?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The blister pack label must display the medicine name, names and quantities/proportions of all active ingredients, batch number with prefix, expiry date with prefix, and sponsor/distributor name or identifying trademark.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 10(9)(a), if a medicine has individual dosage units like suppositories in a blister pack enclosed in a labeled primary pack, the blister pack label needs the medicine name (iv), active ingredient names (v) and quantities (vi), batch number with prefix (vii), expiry date with prefix (viii), and sponsor/distributor name or trademark (ix). Section 9(9) further specifies that Schedule 2 active ingredients must have their names and quantities in at least 2.5mm text size on the main label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists of suppositories individually enclosed in a strip pack, which is enclosed in a primary pack lacking a compliant label, what information must the strip pack label display if an active ingredient is listed in Schedule 2?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If the primary pack label does not comply with sections 8 and 9, the strip pack label alone is insufficient and must fully comply with those sections, including having Schedule 2 active ingredients in at least 2.5mm text size.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) allows a reduced label on strip packs only if the primary pack has a label complying with sections 8 and 9. Without a compliant primary label, section 10(9)(a)(iii) is not met, so the strip label must fully comply itself. Section 9(9) requires Schedule 2 active ingredients to be listed with quantities in minimum 2.5mm text on the main label per sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a single-dose powder medicine is in a sachet enclosed in a primary pack with a label lacking some required information, what must the sachet label display if it contains a Schedule 2 ingredient?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The sachet is considered the primary pack and its label must fully comply with sections 8 and 9, including listing the Schedule 2 active ingredient and its quantity in minimum 2.5mm text size.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) specifies a reduced label is allowed for individually enclosed dosage units only if they are in a strip, blister or dial dispenser pack further enclosed in a labeled primary pack. A single-dose powder sachet does not meet these conditions, so it is considered the primary pack itself. Its label must therefore comply with sections 8 and 9, and section 9(9) mandates that Schedule 2 ingredients be listed by name and quantity in at least 2.5mm text.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming capsules are individually enclosed in unmarked blisters which are in a primary pack having a fully compliant label, what information linking the medicine to its active ingredients must be on the blister pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No information linking the medicine to its active ingredients is required on the blister pack. Only the medicine name must be displayed, not the active ingredient names or quantities.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(a) allows a reduced label on a blister pack if the dosage units can only be extracted individually and the blister is in a primary pack with a label complying with sections 8 and 9. In this case, the blister pack label needs only the information in 10(9)(a)(iv)-(ix). This includes the medicine name (iv) but not the active ingredient names (v) or quantities (vi). Those can be omitted from the blister label since the primary pack has a compliant label.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (1) Preparations for ophthalmic use In addition to the requirements of sections 8 and 9 above, if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use, the label on the container and on the primary pack or, where subsection 10(7) applies, the primary pack, must include: (c) if the medicine is for multidose use - a statement to the effect that ‘the medicine should not be used more than four weeks’, or such shorter period as specified in the approved product details in relation to the medicine, after the container is first opened;

10 Qualifications and special requirements (7) Small containers If: (d) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, unless there are four or more active ingredients; and the following information is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres:

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use and comes in a multidose container, what information must be included on the label of the container regarding the time period the medicine can be used after first opening the container?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include a statement that the medicine should not be used more than four weeks after the container is first opened, or a shorter period if specified in the approved product details for the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1)(c) states that if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use and is for multidose use, the label on the container must include 'a statement to the effect that 'the medicine should not be used more than four weeks', or such shorter period as specified in the approved product details in relation to the medicine, after the container is first opened'.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine comes in a small container and has four or more active ingredients, what information must be displayed on the container in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The following information must be displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres on the small container.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(7)(d) states that if the container is small, the name(s) of all active ingredients do not need to be included on the container 'unless there are four or more active ingredients'. The last part of section 10(7) specifies that 'the following information' must be displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres, referring to the required information listed in sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use and comes in a small multidose container, what information must be included on the label of the container regarding the time period the medicine can be used after first opening?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label on the small multidose container of the ophthalmic preparation must include a statement that the medicine should not be used more than four weeks after first opening, or a shorter period if specified in the approved product details. This information must be displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Combining the requirements from sections 10(1)(c) and 10(7): 10(1)(c) mandates including a statement about the time period of use after opening for ophthalmic multidose medicines. 10(7) allows some information to be omitted on small containers but specifies the mandatory inclusion of 'the following information' in a minimum text size, which refers to the information required by 10(1)(c).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine comes in a small multidose container for ophthalmic use and has five active ingredients, which specific pieces of information are not required to be on the label of the container?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of the active ingredients are not required to be on the label of the small container, since there are more than four active ingredients. However, the time period the medicine can be used after first opening the multidose container must still be included on the label in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres, as this is mandatory for ophthalmic preparations.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(7)(d) allows the names of active ingredients to be omitted from the label of a small container if there are four or more active ingredients. However, section 10(1)(c) still requires the inclusion of the statement about the time period of use after opening for ophthalmic multidose medicines, and section 10(7) mandates this 'following information' must be in a minimum 1.5 millimetre text size on small containers.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (5) If the medicine contains: (c) if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and (i) subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names, and quantities or proportions, of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres; or (ii) subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (c) The information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) may include words describing the purpose of the active ingredient(s) by indicating the pharmacological category or the principal intended actions that are not required by this Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, what information must be displayed on the label regarding the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If a medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) regarding displaying the names and quantities or proportions of active ingredients is not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(ii) states that if the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) relate to displaying the names and quantities or proportions of active ingredients on the label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) does not apply, what is the minimum text size required for displaying the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If a medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(i) specifies that if the medicine is intended to be registered goods and subsection 8(2) does not apply, then the names and quantities or proportions of the active ingredients must be displayed on the side or rear panel or label in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Under subsection 8(2)(c), what additional information may be included along with the pharmacological category when describing the purpose of the active ingredients on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Under subsection 8(2)(c), the information provided may include words describing the principal intended actions of the active ingredients that are not required by this Order, in addition to the pharmacological category.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(c) allows the information provided under paragraph 8(2)(b)(i) to include words describing the purpose of the active ingredient(s) by indicating the pharmacological category or the principal intended actions that are not required by this Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, what specific paragraphs in section 9 are exempted from compliance regarding the display of active ingredient information on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: If a medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) regarding displaying the names and quantities or proportions of active ingredients is not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(5)(c)(ii) explicitly states that if the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. These paragraphs relate to the display of active ingredient information on the label.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (c) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (1) Subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in this section and section 10 of this Order, the information on the main label of the medicine must include: (b) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains five active ingredients and is intended to be registered goods, and subsection 8(2) applies, is compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) required on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 9(7)(c), if the medicine contains four or more active ingredients, is intended to be registered goods, and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required. Paragraph 9(1)(b) states that the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label, subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in section 9 and section 10. However, the special requirement in 9(7)(c) overrides this for medicines with four or more active ingredients when the other conditions are met.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains three active ingredients and is registered goods, and subsection 8(2) does not apply, is compliance with paragraph 9(1)(b) required on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, compliance with paragraph 9(1)(b) is required in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(1)(b) states that the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label, subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in section 9 and section 10. Subsection 9(7)(c) provides a special requirement that exempts medicines with four or more active ingredients from complying with 9(1)(b) if the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies. However, in this case, the medicine only has three active ingredients and subsection 8(2) does not apply, so the special requirement in 9(7)(c) is not relevant. Therefore, the general rule in 9(1)(b) applies and compliance is required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is not intended to be registered goods, contains five active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) applies, is compliance with paragraph 9(1)(c) required on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, compliance with paragraph 9(1)(c) is required in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(1)(c) is mentioned alongside 9(1)(b) as information that must be included on the main label, subject to qualifications and special requirements. Subsection 9(7)(c) provides a special requirement that exempts medicines from complying with 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) if the medicine has four or more active ingredients, is intended to be registered goods, and subsection 8(2) applies. However, in this case, while the medicine has five active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, it is not intended to be registered goods. Therefore, the special requirement in 9(7)(c) does not apply, and compliance with the general rule in 9(1)(c) is still required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains two active ingredients, is registered goods, and subsection 8(2) applies, is compliance with paragraph 9(1)(b) required on the main label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, compliance with paragraph 9(1)(b) is required in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 9(1)(b) states that the names of all active ingredients must be included on the main label, subject to the qualifications and special requirements specified in section 9 and section 10. Subsection 9(7)(c) provides a special requirement that exempts medicines with four or more active ingredients from complying with 9(1)(b) if the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies. In this case, while the medicine is registered goods and subsection 8(2) applies, it only contains two active ingredients, which is less than the four required for the 9(7)(c) exemption. Therefore, the general rule in 9(1)(b) still applies and compliance is required.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (7) Small containers If: (d) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, unless there are four or more active ingredients; and the following information is displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres:

10 Qualifications and special requirements (1) Preparations for ophthalmic use In addition to the requirements of sections 8 and 9 above, if a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use, the label on the container and on the primary pack or, where subsection 10(7) applies, the primary pack, must include: (e) if the medicine consists of a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use - the words ‘for eye drops’.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use and contains three active ingredients, what is the minimum text size required for the names of the active ingredients on the label of the primary pack if the medicine is in a small container?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 1.5 millimetres
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 10(7)(d), if a medicine is in a small container, the names of all active ingredients must be displayed on the label unless there are four or more active ingredients. Since the medicine in question contains three active ingredients, their names must be displayed. Subsection 10(7) also states that for small containers, the required information must be displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres. Therefore, the minimum text size required for the names of the active ingredients on the label of the primary pack is 1.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use and is in a small container, what information must be included on the label of the primary pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label on the primary pack must include the words 'for eye drops' and the names of all active ingredients (unless there are four or more active ingredients) in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 10(1)(e), if a medicine is a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use, the label on the container and on the primary pack must include the words 'for eye drops'. Additionally, subsection 10(7)(d) states that for medicines in small containers, the names of all active ingredients must be displayed on the label unless there are four or more active ingredients. Subsection 10(7) also requires that for small containers, the information must be displayed in a text size of not less than 1.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a preparation for ophthalmic use and is not in a small container, what is the minimum text size required for the names of the active ingredients on the label of the primary pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The regulation does not specify a minimum text size for the names of active ingredients on the label of the primary pack for preparations for ophthalmic use that are not in small containers.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(1) outlines additional requirements for preparations for ophthalmic use, but it does not specify a minimum text size for the names of active ingredients on the label of the primary pack. The minimum text size requirement of 1.5 millimetres mentioned in subsection 10(7) only applies to medicines in small containers. For preparations for ophthalmic use that are not in small containers, the general requirements in sections 8 and 9 would apply, but these sections are not provided in the given context.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use, contains five active ingredients, and is in a small container, what information must be included on the label of the primary pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label on the primary pack must include the words 'for eye drops'. The names of the active ingredients are not required since there are more than four active ingredients.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 10(1)(e), if a medicine is a solid ophthalmic medicine for preparing eye drops for multidose use, the label on the container and on the primary pack must include the words 'for eye drops'. Subsection 10(7)(d) states that for medicines in small containers, the names of all active ingredients must be displayed on the label unless there are four or more active ingredients. Since the medicine in question contains five active ingredients, their names are not required on the label of the primary pack. However, the words 'for eye drops' must still be included as per subsection 10(1)(e).
