contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (9) Strip, blister and dial dispenser packs (b) If, in relation to a medicine referred to in (a) there are: (i) four or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods; or (ii) two or more active ingredients in the medicine and the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods, then, in relation to compliance of the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the following information is displayed: (iii) the name of the medicine; and (iv) the batch number of the medicine preceded by the batch number prefix; and (v) the expiry date of the medicine preceded by the expiry date prefix; and (vi) the name of the sponsor or distributor, or registered trademark if it readily identifies the sponsor or distributor of the medicine.

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (n) a statement of the purpose or purposes for which it is intended that the medicine be used, except where: (i) the medicine is: (A) supplied solely to a complementary healthcare practitioner for supply to a person after affixing by the practitioner of an instruction label on the medicine following a consultation with that person; and (B) the label of the medicine includes the words ‘For Practitioner Dispensing Only’; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is listed goods and contains three active ingredients, is it sufficient for the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack to only display the name of the medicine, batch number, expiry date, and sponsor name to comply with sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 10(9)(b)(ii), if a medicine is listed goods and contains two or more active ingredients, then it is sufficient for the label on the strip, blister or dial dispenser pack to display just the name of the medicine, batch number, expiry date, and sponsor name to comply with sections 8 and 9. However, the question states the medicine has three active ingredients, so this provision does not apply and the label must comply with all the requirements in sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a medicine supplied solely to a complementary healthcare practitioner for dispensing to patients after consultation, assuming the label includes 'For Practitioner Dispensing Only', is it required to include a statement of the intended purpose or purposes of the medicine on the label as per section 8(1)(n)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(n) states that the label must include a statement of intended purpose, except where the medicine is supplied solely to a practitioner for dispensing to patients after consultation, and the label includes 'For Practitioner Dispensing Only'. Both of those conditions are met based on the assumptions in the question, so the exception applies and no statement of purpose is required on the label per 8(1)(n)(i).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Suppose a medicine is registered goods and has five active ingredients. Assuming it is packaged in a blister pack, would the label on the blister pack be compliant with sections 8 and 9 if it only displayed the medicine name, batch number, expiry date, and registered trademark that readily identifies the sponsor?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(i) provides that for a medicine that is registered goods with four or more active ingredients, the label on a strip, blister or dial dispenser pack is deemed compliant with sections 8 and 9 if it displays the medicine name, batch number, expiry date, and sponsor name or identifying trademark. The question states the medicine is registered goods with five active ingredients and is in a blister pack, so this provision applies and the label described would be sufficient.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Consider a listed medicine with one active ingredient that is supplied only to healthcare practitioners for dispensing to their patients. Assuming the label states 'For Practitioner Dispensing Only', does section 10(9)(b) allow the label on the blister packs to omit some of the information required by sections 8 and 9?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(9)(b)(ii) provides a labelling concession for listed medicines in strip, blister or dial dispenser packs, but only if the medicine contains two or more active ingredients. Since this medicine is stated to have only one active ingredient, the concession in 10(9)(b) does not apply, even though the medicine is supplied solely to practitioners for dispensing. The blister pack labels would need to include all information required by sections 8 and 9.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (d) the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately in relation to each formulation of medicine in the composite pack or medicine kit.

9 Information to be included on the main label (6) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, listed goods: (b) if there are four or more active ingredients in the medicine - the name of every active ingredient, together with the quantity or proportion of every active ingredient, may appear on a side panel or side label or on a rear panel or rear label.

11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (c) where paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply- the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine

11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (b) where all active ingredients of the medicine are homoeopathic preparations and are all included in the medicine in the same proportion - as ‘Contains equal parts of ...’ followed by the name of each active ingredient; or

9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (b) not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is: (i) required or permitted by: (A) paragraph 11(2)(h); or (B) subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A); or (C) subsection 11(5); or (ii) in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack or a medicine kit;

11 How information is to be expressed (5) Inclusion of common names of vitamins Where a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, then the word ‘vitamin’, or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label of the medicine either: (b) on a separate line of text - immediately below the related name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin and the quantity of that active ingredient.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, can the word 'vitamin' appear on the main label of the medicine immediately below the related name and quantity of the active ingredient that is a vitamin, on a separate line of text?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 11(5)(b), if a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, the word 'vitamin' or any suitable unambiguous abbreviation of the word vitamin, together with the common name of that vitamin, may appear on a main label of the medicine on a separate line of text, immediately below the related name of the active ingredient that is a vitamin and the quantity of that active ingredient.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming no additional information is required or permitted by other paragraphs or subsections, can the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label be separated by any text or graphics?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(b), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must not be separated by any text or graphics, except where additional information is required or permitted by specific paragraphs or subsections, namely paragraph 11(2)(h), subparagraphs 11(2)(i)(i) or 11(2)(i)(ii)(A), or subsection 11(5).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine contains vitamin C as an active ingredient, can the name 'Vitamin C' appear on the main label immediately below the related name and quantity of ascorbic acid, which is the active ingredient?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to subsection 11(5), if a medicine contains an active ingredient that is a vitamin, the word 'vitamin' together with the common name of that vitamin (in this case, Vitamin C) may appear on the main label of the medicine on a separate line of text, immediately below the related name of the active ingredient (ascorbic acid) and the quantity of that active ingredient, as per 11(5)(b). This is an exception to the rule in paragraph 9(3)(b) which states that the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must not be separated by any text or graphics.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a composite pack contains different formulations of a medicine, can the names of the different formulations be separated from the name of the medicine on the main label by text or graphics?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(b)(ii), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label can be separated by text or graphics if the additional information is in relation to identifying the different formulations of the medicines contained in a composite pack. This is an exception to the general rule stated in 9(3)(b) that the name of the medicine and names of active ingredients must not be separated by any text or graphics.

3 Application - Therapeutic goods to which this Order applies(1) Subject to sections 4 and 5, this Order applies to medicines supplied or for supply in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91 – Standard for labels of prescription and related medicines.

4 Transition arrangements (3) Notwithstanding (1) and (2), medicines imported into or manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date must comply with TGO 69 (2017) if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine that is not a prescription medicine was supplied in Australia on 1 October 2020, and the medicine was manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020, which labelling standard applies to the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 4(3), if a medicine was imported into or manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date, it must comply with TGO 69 (2017) if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017). Since the medicine in question was manufactured before 1 September 2020 and supplied after that date, TGO 69 (2017) applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a related medicine is supplied in Australia on 1 November 2020, and the medicine is not specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91, which labelling standard applies to the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: This Order (Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92)
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 3(1), this Order applies to medicines supplied or for supply in Australia, other than those specified under section 3 of the Therapeutic Goods Order No. 91. Since the related medicine is supplied in Australia and not specified under TGO 91, this Order (TGO 92) applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine was manufactured in Australia on 1 August 2020 and supplied by the sponsor on 1 October 2020, which labelling standard applies to the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: This Order (Therapeutic Goods Order No. 92)
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 4(1) and 4(2), medicines released for supply on or after 1 September 2020 must comply with this Order (TGO 92). Section 4(3) provides an exception for medicines manufactured before 1 September 2020 and supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date. However, since the medicine in question was supplied by the sponsor, the exception does not apply, and this Order (TGO 92) applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a related medicine is supplied in Australia on 1 December 2020, and the medicine was imported into Australia on 1 August 2020 and supplied by a person other than the sponsor, which labelling standard applies to the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 3(1), this Order (TGO 92) generally applies to medicines supplied in Australia. However, section 4(3) provides an exception for medicines imported into or manufactured in Australia before 1 September 2020 but supplied by a person other than the sponsor after that date. In this case, the related medicine must comply with TGO 69 (2017) if at the time of their release for supply they complied with TGO 69 (2017).

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (8) Individually wrapped medicines (b) If: (i) the medicine consists only of pastilles or lozenges; and (ii) each dosage unit is enclosed in an unsealed individual wrapper; and (iii) each dosage unit is, after being so wrapped, enclosed in a primary pack that complies with sections 8 and 9, then, in relation to compliance of the label for each individual wrapper with sections 8 and 9, it shall be sufficient if the name of the medicine is displayed.

9 Information to be included on the main label (9) If the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, and the name of an active ingredient included in the medicine comprises an ingredient name specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, either alone or in combination with any other descriptors, then the names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine consists only of pastilles or lozenges, with each dosage unit enclosed in an individual unsealed wrapper and then enclosed in a primary pack that complies with sections 8 and 9, what information must be displayed on the label of each individual wrapper to comply with those sections?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 10(8)(b), if a medicine consists only of pastilles or lozenges, with each dosage unit enclosed in an unsealed individual wrapper and then enclosed in a compliant primary pack, then it is sufficient for the label on each individual wrapper to display just the name of the medicine in order to comply with sections 8 and 9.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a registered medicine contains an active ingredient whose name is specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, what information about the active ingredients must be displayed on the main label and in what minimum text size?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of all active ingredients in the medicine, together with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed in a text size of not less than 2.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 9(9) states that if a registered medicine contains an active ingredient whose name is specified in Schedule 2 to this Order, then the names of all active ingredients, along with their quantity or proportion, must be displayed on the main label in a text size of at least 2.5 millimetres.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a registered medicine consists only of lozenges, with each lozenge wrapped individually in an unsealed wrapper and then enclosed in a primary pack, and the medicine contains an active ingredient listed in Schedule 2, what information must be on the individual wrapper labels and the primary pack label respectively?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The individual wrapper labels must display at least the name of the medicine. The primary pack label must display the names of all active ingredients along with their quantity or proportion, in a text size of at least 2.5 millimetres.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Combining the requirements from sections 10(8)(b) and 9(9): 10(8)(b) allows the individual unsealed wrapper labels to display just the medicine name, provided the lozenges are in a compliant primary pack. 9(9) requires the primary pack label to list all active ingredients and their quantities/proportions in minimum 2.5mm text, since the medicine contains a Schedule 2 ingredient and is registered.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming an individually wrapped registered medicine consists of lozenges and contains a Schedule 2 ingredient, and the primary pack label lists all active ingredients with their quantities in 2.5mm text, is any other information required on the individual wrapper labels for them to be compliant?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, no other information is required on the individual wrapper labels in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 10(8)(b) states that for individually wrapped lozenges in a compliant primary pack, it is sufficient for the individual wrapper labels to display just the name of the medicine to be considered compliant with sections 8 and 9. Since section 9(9)'s requirements for Schedule 2 ingredients are met on the primary pack label, no additional information beyond the medicine name is needed on the individual wrappers.

contexts: 10 Qualifications and special requirements (5) Sunscreen preparations If: (a) the medicine is a sunscreen preparation; and

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (l) directions for use of the medicine except where: (i) the dose of the medicine is usually determined for each individual patient by a health professional authorised under a law of a State or Territory to determine the dose; or (ii) there is insufficient space on the label of either the container or the primary pack, or both, to include directions for use, and: (A) those directions for use are set out in a package insert provided in the primary pack of the medicine; and (B) a statement is included on whichever label on the container, or the primary pack, or both, that does not set out the directions for use itself, that those directions are set out in the package insert; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a sunscreen preparation medicine has a primary pack container with insufficient space on the label to include directions for use, and those directions are instead provided in a package insert, what statement must be included on the label of the container or primary pack that does not include the directions?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: A statement that the directions for use are set out in the package insert must be included on whichever label (on the container or primary pack) that does not set out the directions for use itself.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(ii)(B) states that if there is insufficient space on the label of either the container or the primary pack to include directions for use, and those directions are set out in a package insert, a statement must be included on whichever label (on the container or primary pack) that does not set out the directions for use itself, indicating that the directions are in the package insert.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is a sunscreen preparation, and the dose is usually determined for each individual patient by an authorized health professional, are the directions for use of the medicine required to be included on the label of the primary pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the directions for use are not required on the label of the primary pack in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(i) provides an exception to the requirement to include directions for use on medicine labels if the dose is usually determined for each individual patient by an authorized health professional. Section 10(5)(a) specifies that this applies if the medicine is a sunscreen preparation.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a sunscreen preparation medicine has a primary pack with sufficient space on the label to include full directions for use, are those directions required to be on the label of the primary pack?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Yes, the directions for use must be included on the label of the primary pack in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l) requires directions for use to be included on medicine labels, subject to the exceptions in 8(1)(l)(i) and (ii). Those exceptions only apply if the dose is individually determined by a health professional, or if there is insufficient label space and the directions are in a package insert. Neither exception applies here for a sunscreen preparation with sufficient label space, so the general requirement to include directions on the primary pack label remains in effect per 8(1)(l).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a sunscreen preparation medicine has a dose that is not usually individually determined by a health professional, but the primary pack has insufficient label space for full directions, what are the two requirements that must be met regarding the directions for use?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The two requirements are: 1) The full directions for use must be set out in a package insert provided in the primary pack. 2) A statement must be included on the label of either the container or primary pack (whichever does not have the full directions) indicating that the directions are provided in the package insert.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(ii) allows the directions to be omitted from the label only if: (A) the directions are set out in a package insert in the primary pack, and (B) there is a statement on either the container or primary pack label (whichever one does not have the full directions) stating that the directions are in the package insert. Both of these requirements must be met for a sunscreen preparation where the dose is not individually determined, but there is insufficient label space for the directions, per the combination of Sections 8(1)(l)(ii) and 10(5)(a).

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "critical health information" means information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) of this Order, that is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (b) the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the label for an adult cold medicine is compliant with the Order, what information about the medicine's active ingredients must be included on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of all active ingredients in the medicine must be included on the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Order, the labels of a medicine must include the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10. This information is considered critical health information as per paragraph 6 of the Order.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the given sections of the Order, if a consumer is self-selecting an over-the-counter pain relief medicine, what critical health information must be present on the label to ensure safe use?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the names of all active ingredients in the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 6 of the Order defines 'critical health information' as information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n), which is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer. Paragraph 8(1)(b) specifically requires the label to include the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine, subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Under the assumption that no exemptions or additional requirements apply, what information does the Order mandate to be on the label of a non-prescription medicine to ensure consumers can identify the active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the names of all active ingredients in the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Order states that, subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10, the labels of a medicine must include the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine. This information is considered critical health information according to paragraph 6, as it is required for the safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Supposing a consumer is selecting an over-the-counter allergy medicine without the assistance of a healthcare professional, and assuming no additional requirements or exemptions apply, what critical information must be on the label to ensure the consumer can safely use the medicine?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include the names of all active ingredients in the allergy medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Paragraph 6 of the Order defines 'critical health information' as information that is critical for the safe use of medicines self-selected by a consumer, which includes the information required under paragraph 8(1)(b). Paragraph 8(1)(b) mandates that, subject to subsections 8(2), 8(3), and sections 9 and 10, the label must include the name(s) of all active ingredients in the medicine.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (c) if the medicine is: (i) supplied in either a small or a medium container; and (ii) contains multiple active ingredients then, in relation to compliance of the label with paragraph 9(3)(a), the names of the multiple active ingredients and their quantities may be presented together on a continuous line, or lines, of text.

9 Information to be included on the main label (3) Subject to paragraph (c), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must: (a) appear as a cohesive unit by the placing of the name and quantity of each active ingredient together on separate lines of text either (i) immediately below the name of the medicine; or (ii) where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured, adjacent to the name of the medicine; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in a small container and contains multiple active ingredients, what are the requirements for displaying the names and quantities of the active ingredients on the main label in order to be compliant with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities of the multiple active ingredients may be presented together on a continuous line or lines of text.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(c), if a medicine is supplied in either a small or medium container and contains multiple active ingredients, then in relation to compliance with paragraph 9(3)(a), the names of the multiple active ingredients and their quantities may be presented together on a continuous line or lines of text.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in a large container and contains a single active ingredient, what are the requirements for displaying the name and quantity of the active ingredient on the main label in order to be compliant with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name and quantity of the active ingredient must appear as a cohesive unit, either immediately below the name of the medicine or adjacent to the name of the medicine if the trademark might be disrupted or obscured.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(a), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must appear as a cohesive unit by placing the name and quantity of each active ingredient together on separate lines of text either immediately below the name of the medicine or, where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured, adjacent to the name of the medicine. Paragraph 9(3)(c) provides an exception for medicines in small or medium containers with multiple active ingredients, but this question assumes a large container with a single active ingredient, so paragraph 9(3)(a) applies.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in a medium container, contains multiple active ingredients, and has a trademark that might be disrupted by placing the active ingredients immediately below the medicine name, what are the requirements for displaying the names and quantities of the active ingredients on the main label in order to be compliant with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names and quantities of the multiple active ingredients may be presented together on a continuous line or lines of text adjacent to the name of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(a), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must appear as a cohesive unit either immediately below the name of the medicine or, where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured, adjacent to the name of the medicine. Paragraph 9(3)(c) provides an additional option for medicines in small or medium containers with multiple active ingredients, allowing the names and quantities to be presented together on a continuous line or lines of text. Since this question assumes a medium container with multiple active ingredients and a trademark that might be disrupted, the names and quantities may be placed adjacent to the name of the medicine on a continuous line or lines of text to maintain compliance.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine is supplied in a large container and contains multiple active ingredients, what are the requirements for displaying the names and quantities of the active ingredients on the main label in order to be compliant with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name and quantity of each active ingredient must appear as a cohesive unit on separate lines of text, either immediately below the name of the medicine or adjacent to the name of the medicine if the trademark might be disrupted or obscured.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to paragraph 9(3)(a), the name of the medicine and the name(s) of active ingredient(s) on the main label must appear as a cohesive unit by placing the name and quantity of each active ingredient together on separate lines of text either immediately below the name of the medicine or, where the trademark of the medicine might be disrupted or obscured, adjacent to the name of the medicine. Paragraph 9(3)(c) provides an exception for medicines in small or medium containers with multiple active ingredients, but this question assumes a large container, so paragraph 9(3)(a) applies, requiring the name and quantity of each active ingredient to be on separate lines of text.

contexts: 11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (c) where paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply- the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine

11 How information is to be expressed (3) Expression of quantity or proportion of active ingredients for homoeopathic preparations The label on the container and on the primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include: (a) where the medicine is a fully potentised, single ingredient, homoeopathic medicine and it is clear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine – the name of the active ingredient; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic medicine contains a single, fully potentised ingredient, what information must be included on the label of the container and primary pack regarding the quantity or proportion of active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The name of the active ingredient.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(3)(a), if a homoeopathic medicine contains a single, fully potentised ingredient and it is clear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine, the label on the container and primary pack must include the name of the active ingredient.

QuestionAnswers.Question: In cases where a homoeopathic medicine does not meet the criteria in section 11(3)(a) or 11(3)(b), what information must be included on the label of the container and primary pack regarding the quantity or proportion of the homoeopathic preparation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(3)(c) states that where paragraphs (a) and (b) do not apply, the label on the container and primary pack of a medicine that contains a homoeopathic preparation must include the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic medicine contains a single, fully potentised ingredient, and it is unclear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine, what information must be included on the label of the container and primary pack regarding the quantity or proportion of active ingredients?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: According to section 11(3)(a), the name of the active ingredient is only required on the label if the homoeopathic medicine contains a single, fully potentised ingredient and it is clear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine. If it is unclear that the ingredient comprises 100% of the medicine, section 11(3)(c) applies, requiring the label to include the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a homoeopathic medicine does not contain a single, fully potentised ingredient, what information must be included on the label of the container and primary pack regarding the quantity or proportion of the homoeopathic preparation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 11(3)(a) only applies to homoeopathic medicines containing a single, fully potentised ingredient. If the medicine does not meet this criterion, section 11(3)(c) applies, requiring the label on the container and primary pack to include the quantity of the preparation in one millilitre or in one gram of the medicine.

contexts: 6 Interpretation. "critical health information" means information required under paragraphs 8(1)(b), (c), (j), (k), (l) and (n) of this Order, that is critical for safe use of medicines that are self-selected by a consumer;

8 Information to be included on the label (1) Subject to the qualifications and requirements specified in subsections 8(2) and 8(3) and sections 9 and 10 below, the labels of a medicine must include: (l) directions for use of the medicine except where: (i) the dose of the medicine is usually determined for each individual patient by a health professional authorised under a law of a State or Territory to determine the dose; or (ii) there is insufficient space on the label of either the container or the primary pack, or both, to include directions for use, and: (A) those directions for use are set out in a package insert provided in the primary pack of the medicine; and (B) a statement is included on whichever label on the container, or the primary pack, or both, that does not set out the directions for use itself, that those directions are set out in the package insert; and

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine's label does not contain directions for use and there is insufficient space on the container and primary pack labels to include them, what two conditions must be met for the medicine to still comply with the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine label can omit directions for use if there is insufficient label space, provided that: (A) the directions are included in a package insert in the primary pack, and (B) the label that lacks the directions includes a statement referring to the package insert.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(ii) allows directions for use to be omitted from the label if space is insufficient, as long as the specified conditions (A) and (B) are satisfied. Condition (A) requires the directions to be provided in a package insert, and condition (B) requires the label to include a statement pointing to that insert.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine's dose is usually determined for each patient by an authorized health professional, is the medicine's label required to include directions for use?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: No, the label is not required to include directions for use in this case.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(i) provides an exception to the general requirement that labels include directions for use. If the dose is usually determined for each patient by an appropriately authorized health professional, the directions for use may be omitted from the label.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming there is sufficient label space, a medicine's dose is not individually determined, and no other exceptions apply, what specific information regarding directions for use of the medicine is required on the label to ensure safe use by consumers?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The label must include directions for use of the medicine, as this is critical health information required for safe use by consumers who self-select the medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l) requires labels to include directions for use, subject to specific exceptions. Section 6 defines "critical health information" that is required for safe use of self-selected medicines as including the information under 8(1)(l). Therefore, assuming no exceptions apply, the directions for use must be on the label to meet the critical health information requirement.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine label omits directions for use under the exception in 8(1)(l)(ii), what specific label statement regarding the location of the directions is necessary to comply with the regulation's critical health information requirements for safe use?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: When directions for use are omitted from a label under 8(1)(l)(ii), the label must include a statement that the directions are provided in the package insert, in order to meet the regulation's critical health information requirements for safe use defined in section 6.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(1)(l)(ii)(B) requires a statement on the label pointing to the package insert when directions are omitted due to insufficient space. Section 6 specifies that the 8(1)(l) directions are "critical health information" for safe use. Therefore, the mandated statement is necessary to satisfy the section 6 requirements in this circumstance.

contexts: 8 Information to be included on the label (2) (e) If information other than the critical health information or information of a kind mentioned in subsections 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is to be included, it must be placed under the ‘Other information’ heading or under another separate appropriate heading(s) that follow immediately below the headings mentioned in 8(2)(b) and must not contain any additional information other than: A. requirements relating to storage conditions B. information about package features to prevent tampering C. names of all excipients D. sponsor or distributor contact details.

8 Information to be included on the label (2) (b) The critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the following order: (i) Active ingredients (ii) Indications (iii) Warnings (iv) Directions for use (v) Other information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming that 'Active ingredients', 'Indications', 'Warnings', and 'Directions for use' are considered critical health information in subsections 8(2)(c), what order must this critical health information appear in on the label according to the regulation?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The critical health information must appear in the following order: (i) Active ingredients (ii) Indications (iii) Warnings (iv) Directions for use.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Section 8(2)(b) states that the critical health information must be presented under appropriate headings and in the specified order of (i) Active ingredients (ii) Indications (iii) Warnings (iv) Directions for use (v) Other information. This directly answers the question of what order the critical health information must appear in.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on the information in subsections 8(2)(b), 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(e), under what heading should sponsor or distributor contact details be placed on the label, assuming they are not considered critical health information?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: Sponsor or distributor contact details should be placed under the 'Other information' heading or under another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the critical health information headings.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 8(2)(b) specifies the order of critical health information headings. Subsection 8(2)(e) then states that if information other than the critical health information or information mentioned in 8(2)(c) or 8(2)(d) is included, it must be placed under the 'Other information' heading or another appropriate heading that follows immediately below the critical health information headings. Sponsor or distributor contact details are listed as an example of such other information in 8(2)(e).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming the names of all excipients are not considered critical health information or the type of information described in subsections 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(d), under what heading should the excipient names appear according to the regulation order specified in subsections 8(2)(b) and 8(2)(e)?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The names of all excipients should appear under the 'Other information' heading or under another separate appropriate heading that follows immediately below the critical health information headings specified in 8(2)(b).
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 8(2)(b) lists the order of critical health information headings. Subsection 8(2)(e) states that information not considered critical health information or the information in 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(d) must be placed under 'Other information' or another appropriate heading following the critical health information headings. 8(2)(e) lists 'names of all excipients' as an example of such other information.

QuestionAnswers.Question: Based on subsections 8(2)(b), 8(2)(c) and 8(2)(e), if 'Directions for use' is considered critical health information but information about package features to prevent tampering is not, in what order should those two types of information appear on the label?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: 'Directions for use' should appear before information about package features to prevent tampering on the label.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 8(2)(b) specifies that critical health information like 'Directions for use' must appear in the listed order, with 'Directions for use' as the fourth item. Then 8(2)(e) states that other information not considered critical health information, with package tampering features given as an example, must be placed under 'Other information' or another heading that follows after the critical health information headings from 8(2)(b). Therefore, 'Directions for use' would come before the tamper evident packaging information on the label.

contexts: 9 Information to be included on the main label (8) Where a medicine is: (d) the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) must be provided separately in relation to each formulation of medicine in the composite pack or medicine kit.

9 Information to be included on the main label (7) Subject to subsection 9(9), if the medicine is intended to be, or is, registered goods, then: (c) where the medicine contains four or more active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applies, then compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required; or

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a medicine kit contains two different formulations of medicine that are registered goods, and one of the formulations contains five active ingredients with subsection 8(2) applying, what information must be provided on the main label for each formulation to ensure compliance?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine kit must provide the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) separately for each formulation. However, for the formulation with five active ingredients where subsection 8(2) applies, compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Subsection 9(8)(d) states that for a composite pack or medicine kit, the information required under 9(6)(b) or 9(7) must be provided separately for each medicine formulation. Subsection 9(7)(c) specifies that for registered goods with four or more active ingredients where 8(2) applies, compliance with 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required.

QuestionAnswers.Question: For a registered composite pack containing three medicines, two with three active ingredients each and one with five active ingredients where subsection 8(2) applies, what labeling is required to ensure compliance?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The composite pack must provide the information required under either 9(6)(b) or 9(7) separately for each of the three medicines. For the two medicines with three active ingredients, 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) must be complied with. For the medicine with five active ingredients where 8(2) applies, 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) compliance is not required.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: Per 9(8)(d), a composite pack must provide the 9(6)(b) or 9(7) information separately for each medicine. 9(7)(c) waives the 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) requirements only for registered medicines with four or more active ingredients where 8(2) applies. The two 3-ingredient medicines do not meet this criteria and must follow 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c).

QuestionAnswers.Question: Assuming a registered composite pack contains two medicines, both with six active ingredients and subsection 8(2) applying to each, what main label information is needed for compliance?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The composite pack must provide the information required under either paragraph 9(6)(b) or subsection 9(7) separately for each of the two component medicines. Since both medicines contain more than four active ingredients and 8(2) applies, compliance with paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) is not required for either medicine.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(8)(d) requires composite packs to separately provide the 9(6)(b) or 9(7) information for each component medicine. Per 9(7)(c), registered medicines with four or more active ingredients where 8(2) applies do not need to comply with 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c). Since both medicines in the pack meet this criteria, neither needs to follow 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c).

QuestionAnswers.Question: For an unregistered medicine kit with two formulations, one containing three and the other seven active ingredients, and subsection 8(2) applying to the 7-ingredient formulation, what main label information ensures compliance?
QuestionAnswers.Answer: The medicine kit must provide the information required under paragraph 9(6)(b) separately for each formulation, as subsection 9(7) only applies to registered goods. This means paragraphs 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) must be complied with for both the 3-ingredient and 7-ingredient formulations, even though 8(2) applies to the 7-ingredient one.
QuestionAnswers.Answer Explanation: 9(8)(d) requires medicine kits to provide the 9(6)(b) information separately for each component medicine formulation. The 9(7)(c) exception that waives 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c) compliance for medicines with 4+ ingredients where 8(2) applies is limited to registered goods only. As this kit is unregistered, both formulations must follow 9(1)(b) and 9(1)(c).
